column1: ## v : active/passive: indicative/subjunctive : type : paradigm / exemplar / irregular
# v: a/p : i/s : finite / infinitive / participle /
*Irregular verb: possum (pot + esse)- to be able to
*Irregular verb: possum (pot + esse) to be able to / can

column7: but irregular in that the vowel following the root fer- is sometimes omitted. The perfect tense tulī and supine stem lātum are also irregularly formed.

column6: to be made" as well as being a verb in its own right serves as the passive of faciō
column10: to make". The perfect tenses are identical with the perfect passive tenses of faciō.

column1: Present active	laudāre	terrēre	petere	capere	audīre
Present passive	laudārī	terrērī	petī	capī	audīrī
Perfect active	laudāvisse	terruisse	petīvisse	cēpisse	audīvisse
Perfect passive	laudātus esse	territus esse	petītus esse	captus esse	audītus esse
Future active	laudātūrus esse	territūrus esse	petītūrus esse	captūrus esse	audītūrus esse
Future passive	laudātum īrī	territum īrī	petītum īrī	captum īrī	audītum īrī
Potential	laudātūrus fuisse	territūrus fuisse	petītūrus fuisse	captūrus fuisse	audītūrus fuisse
Accusative	laudātum	territum	petītum	captum	audītum
Ablative	laudātū	territū	petītū	captū	audītū
*The gerund is formed similarly to the present active participle. However
column3: and the preceding ā or ē is shortened. Gerunds are neuter nouns of the second declension
column4: but the nominative case is not present. The gerund is a noun
column6: and forms a suppletive paradigm to the infinitive
column7: which cannot be declined. For example
column8: the genitive form laudandī can mean "of praising"
column9: the dative form laudandō can mean "for praising"
column10: the accusative form laudandum can mean "praising"
column11: and the ablative form laudandō can mean "by praising"

column1: *One common use of the gerund is with the preposition ad to indicate purpose. For example
column2: paratus ad oppugnandum could be translated as "ready to attack". However the gerund was avoided when an object was introduced
column3: and a passive construction with the gerundive was preferred. For example
column4: for "ready to attack the enemy" the construction paratus ad hostes oppugnandos is preferred over paratus ad hostes oppugnandum.

column1: Accusative	laudandum	terrendum	petendum	capiendum	audiendum
Genitive	laudandī	terrendī	petendī	capiendī	audiendī
Dative	laudandō	terrendō	petendō	capiendō	audiendō
Ablative	laudandō	terrendō	petendō	capiendō	audiendō
*The gerundive has a form similar to that of the gerund
column2: but it is a first and second declension adjective
column3: and functions as a future passive participle. It means "(which is) to be ...ed". Often
column4: the gerundive is used with part of the verb esse

column1: *The first periphrastic conjugation uses the future participle. It is combined with the forms of esse. It is translated as "I am going to praise
Pres. ind.	laudātūrus sum	I am going to praise
Imp. ind.	laudātūrus eram	I was going to praise
Fut. ind.	laudātūrus erō	I will be going to praise
Perf. ind.	laudātūrus fuī	I have been going to praise
Plup. ind.	laudātūrus fueram	I had been going to praise
Fut. perf. ind.	laudātūrus fuerō	I will have been going to praise
Pres. subj.	laudātūrus sim	I may be going to praise
Imp. subj.	laudātūrus essem	I should be going to praise
Perf. subj.	laudātūrus fuerim	I may have been going to praise
Plup. subj.	laudātūrus fuissem	I should have been going to praise
*The second periphrastic conjugation uses the gerundive. It is combined with the forms of esse and expresses necessity. It is translated as "I am needing to be praised"
column4: or as "I have to (must) be praised"
column6:
etc.

Tense + mood	Conjugation	Translation
Pres. ind.	laudandus sum	I am needing to be praised
Imp. ind.	laudandus eram	I was needing to be praised
Fut. ind.	laudandus erō	I will be needing to be praised
Perf. ind.	laudandus fuī	I was needing to be praised
Plup. ind.	laudandus fueram	I had been needing to be praised
Fut. perf. ind.	laudandus fuerō	I will have been needing to be praised
Pres. subj.	laudandus sim	I may be needing to be praised
Imp. subj.	laudandus essem	I should be needing to be praised
Perf. subj.	laudandus fuerim	I may have been needing to be praised
Plup. subj.	laudandus fuissem	I should have been needing to be praised
Pres. inf.	laudandus esse	To be needing to be praised
Perf. inf.	laudandus fuisse	To have been needing to be praised

&v:i=for:e
* For: Parts
Part	Form
Present Active Participle	fāns, fantis
Present Active Infinitive	fārī (variant: fārier)
Supine	(acc.) fātum, (abl.) fātū
Gerund	(gen.) fandī, (dat. and abl.) fandō, no accusative
Gerundive	fandus, –a, –um


&v:impersonal:e
*Impersonal verbs
*Impersonal verbs are those lacking a person. In English impersonal verbs are usually used with the neuter pronoun it" (as in "It seems
column7: or it is raining"). Latin uses the third person singular. These verbs lack a fourth principal part. A few examples are:

column1: pluit	pluere	plūvit/pluit	to rain (it rains)
ningit	ningere	ninxit	to snow (it snows)
oportet	oportēre	oportuit	to be proper (it is proper
licet	licēre	licuit	to be permitted [to] (it is allowed [to])
*The future active participle is normally formed by removing the –um from the supine
Pres active infin	Supine Fut active part	Meaning
iuvāre	iūtum	iuvātūrus	going to help
lavāre/lavere	lavātum (but PPP lautus)	lavātūrus	going to wash
parere	partum	paritūrus	going to produce
ruere	rutum	ruitūrus	going to fall
secāre	sectum	secātūrus	going to cut
fruī	frūctum/fruitum	fruitūrus	going to enjoy
nāscī	nātum	nātūrus/nascitūrus	going to be born
morī	mortuum	moritūrus	going to die
orīrī	ortum	oritūrus	going to rise
